creditline: The Driscoll Art Accessions Endowment Fund and Gift of Dr. Terrence Brayboy
life_date: North America, Great Lakes or Woodlands region
text: The designs on this bandolier bag reference important elements in traditional Anishinabe life.  The repeating geometric floral patterns, shown on the central panel and strap, refer to the natural environment that the Anishinabe depend on.  The beaded design that can be found on the outside of the central beaded panel refers to the otter, who plays an important role in Anishinabe stories and clan system.  The series of diamonds followed by straight lines, then diamonds, refer to the otter tracks.  The diamonds symbolize footprints, and the straight lines are the otter's tail.  This bandolier bag is a testimony of Anishinabe artistic skill and creativity.
title: Bandolier Bag
